Input.threadtitle: How did it come about that tv often focuses on marriage and the nuclear family?
Input.posts:
Great job Jeanine. I'm on lecture 2 and wondering about the huge dichotomy between film's avoidance of marriage and tv's focus on marriage and the family. Would love to hear your analysis on story structure, marriage and tv. Ralph Cramden and Alice and how you would analyze the portrayal of couples over the years as brought to us by the before little box.
Upvotes:
4
Jim, remember that one thing that TV has is TIME. Think of all the hours of I LOVE LUCY - and how that meant they could go through so many different moments of a marriage. They didn't have to sort everything out in 90 minutes, as Jeanine said. Or the way that something like THE SOPRANOS - it's most definitely NOT a marriage show. But because of the extra time it can go into the whole marriage journey over the number of years of the program, at the same time it gives us the drama of the Mob story. And that's without mentioning the daytime soaps which can last longer than a marriage! I'd say there's also the element of television meeting the audience somewhere near where it is, even when exaggerated - e.g Leave it To Beaver, Brady Bunch,Rosanne The audience instantly recognises themselves and can settle in to see variations of themselves, with an element of wish fulfillment and fantasy. Great for capturing them for the advertisers!
Upvotes:
5
I agree. The television format allows more time to develop character and also to insert external conflict. TV couples seem to have remained steady-ish over the years. Few, if any, sitcoms deal with divorce other than a 'very special episode'. The sitcom is especially ideal for portraying marriage since they're typically episodic rather than serial. Nothing fundamentally changes in the characters from episode to episode.
Upvotes:
0
The afternoon soap operas operate in just the way that Jeanine has suggested: bringing a couple together just to break them up to see whether that couple might get back together again. For the long running soaps, unlike prime time television where the whole family is expected to gather around to watch, separation and divorce seem to have been woven in as part of the plot (or formula) for a much longer time.

0
Jim, as I watched the early lectures I wondered the same thing. The examples that came to my mind were Ozzie and Harriet, Father Knows Best, and Leave it to Beaver...or even Married with Children. Richard, I think your point about the episodic nature of tv is accurate. This leads me to wonder about a relatively recent trend, binge watching, where the viewer watches one episode after the other in a short time span. My wife and I indulge in this sometimes. More than one series that we might have enjoyed for years, if the scenes were properly spaced apart, has ended up becoming somewhat boring when watched all at once. Oddly enough, there are some that benefited from this watching style. I am curious whether directors take these viewing habits into account when planning their shows. I'm not sure why this thread is marked 'resolved' as I didn't think it described a problem...hope people will get to read what I said.

2
Yeah, serial forms of storytelling have a strong bias towards maintaining something of a sense of a status quo, as that is how they maintain their form over significant lengths of time. By that I mean something like a tv series is generally going to be based around some set of characters or a specific place, so people tuning into the series will have the expectation of those things being the heart of the show and thus continue to be followed throughout its run. This may not absolutely prevent change, but it does place some limits on the amount of it or the likelihood of significant amounts of it occurring from episode to episode. This then makes some stories much better suited to the serial form. For much of US television history, tv series were designed to be episodic, essentially 20ish or 40ish minute short films where a situation is introduced and resolved within the duration of a single episode by a familiar cast of characters. This relates to something the professor was talking about with the early two reelers, where there was often a very simple structure to the movies in part due to the time limits imposed, and where the audience had some familiarity with the personae of the stars involved, so even if they weren't playing the exact same characters from short to short, they were playing essentially similar characters in new situations. The tv equivalent would be to keep the same characters in some job perhaps where new events would occur each weeks with new guest stars, but the basics of the show from week to week were the same. Shows like Highway Patrol, Perry Mason, Sea Hunt and so on worked in that manner. Shows revolving around families, couples or slightly bigger casts of set characters pushed this a little further, where the place and cast were largely the same from week to week, but some minor issue occurred that somehow posed a problem that needed to be solved for the cast. The key then for that formula to work is one of stability, and marriage and families are ideal for that. Plenty of shows have tried other formulas of course, but there is often some difficulty in maintaining stability when introducing something like, say, the typical boy meets girl romantic comedy formula. That form can work well for a while, and has proven to be quite popular on tv in various guises, but eventually the show runs into increasing difficulties in both finding ways to keep the attraction, and interest in the attraction, between the couple strong while continuing to find excuses to keep them apart. The shows often become either tired or desperate seeming in their attempts to maintain interest in that way. Marriage doesn't have that problem. The situation is set up to be more or less stable, so the problems in the show, while perhaps causing conflict, aren't going to have to be justified in how they might affect the central relationships in the show sense the social expectation is that the family unit will remain together no matter what happens for the most part. Feature films, in contrast, have a strong bias for some change occurring over the length of the film, where the idea is to get the characters from place A to place B, leaving them in a altered situation from where we first saw them. This, of course, makes for some difficulties for movies about marriage, which the professor is addressing.

5
I think it is due to placement as well. Televisions are in our front rooms, the heart of the family. Work and family are the two situations that take up most of our time, so that is another reason, I think. Also, I find it interesting the way the definition of marriage and family has changed on TV over time. Work as a surrogate for family can be seen starting in the 60s and 70s with Dick Van Dyke, Mary Tyler Moore, and Taxi. There was also a 'family is what you make of it' theme with Three's Company, Friends, even The Odd Couple. And I find How I Met Your Mother an interesting tale. On the one hand, the director still wants to show that marriage matters. On the other hand, the reality is that people are getting married later, and will have multiple romantic relationships before and after a marriage. HIMYM was able to capture all of that.

4
I think you have even more truth here than you might be aware of. TV and the shift in format lets it move away from 'arc' and into liminal space - and that totally changes the story & character dynamics. One point of interest that shows the shift (since the very influential show I Love Lucy has been mentioned) is that the 'romance' arc of Lucy and Ricky was shown in a *movie* special (shown on television - but 75 min long) - Lucy Takes a Cruise to Havana - sponsored by the Ford Motor Company. (1957) This comes after the series proper (I love Lucy ran from 51 to 57). Even though the characters were well established - when they changed format they went 'back in time' to a romance story instead of a 'married' story. This reflects what was said about the difference stories that were considered proper to the different formats.

Instructor's Post
Yes, I definitely think there are some subject matter differences that have been facilitated by the differences in the two media. At the most practical level, episodic TV productions generally are working with much smaller budgets per episode than a feature film would be, so they tend to be more studio or set bound (particularly in earlier 'live' TV and the classic sitcom model where they were shooting in front of a studio audience), and it generally was as fast and cheap to create sets for an American contemporary domestic setting as it was any other sort of feasible set rather than either real or constructed exotic locales often used in films. Oh, and I should also say that I think the prevalence of 'family' comedy and drama on TV is a partial explanation of why we don't see more of it in Hollywood films--over the years a sort of division of labor developed between the two media.

Yeah, serial forms of storytelling have a strong bias towards maintaining something of a sense of a status quo, as that is how they maintain their form over significant lengths of time. By that I mean something like a tv series is generally going to be based around some set of characters or a specific place, so people tuning into the series will have the expectation of those things being the heart of the show and thus continue to be followed throughout its run. This may not absolutely prevent change, but it does place some limits on the amount of it or the likelihood of significant amounts of it occurring from episode to episode. This then makes some stories much better suited to the serial form. For much of US television history, tv series were designed to be episodic, essentially 20ish or 40ish minute short films where a situation is introduced and resolved within the duration of a single episode by a familiar cast of characters. This relates to something the professor was talking about with the early two reelers, where there was often a very simple structure to the movies in part due to the time limits imposed, and where the audience had some familiarity with the personae of the stars involved, so even if they weren't playing the exact same characters from short to short, they were playing essentially similar characters in new situations. The tv equivalent would be to keep the same characters in some job perhaps where new events would occur each weeks with new guest stars, but the basics of the show from week to week were the same. Shows like Highway Patrol, Perry Mason, Sea Hunt and so on worked in that manner. Shows revolving around families, couples or slightly bigger casts of set characters pushed this a little further, where the place and cast were largely the same from week to week, but some minor issue occurred that somehow posed a problem that needed to be solved for the cast. The key then for that formula to work is one of stability, and marriage and families are ideal for that. Plenty of shows have tried other formulas of course, but there is often some difficulty in maintaining stability when introducing something like, say, the typical boy meets girl romantic comedy formula. That form can work well for a while, and has proven to be quite popular on tv in various guises, but eventually the show runs into increasing difficulties in both finding ways to keep the attraction, and interest in the attraction, between the couple strong while continuing to find excuses to keep them apart. The shows often become either tired or desperate seeming in their attempts to maintain interest in that way. Marriage doesn't have that problem. The situation is set up to be more or less stable, so the problems in the show, while perhaps causing conflict, aren't going to have to be justified in how they might affect the central relationships in the show sense the social expectation is that the family unit will remain together no matter what happens for the most part. Feature films, in contrast, have a strong bias for some change occurring over the length of the film, where the idea is to get the characters from place A to place B, leaving them in a altered situation from where we first saw them. This, of course, makes for some difficulties for movies about marriage, which the professor is addressing.

At the most practical level, episodic TV productions generally are working with much smaller budgets per episode than a feature film would be, so they tend to be more studio or set bound (particularly in earlier 'live' TV and the classic sitcom model where they were shooting in front of a studio audience), and it generally was as fast and cheap to create sets for an American contemporary domestic setting as it was any other sort of feasible set rather than either real or constructed exotic locales often used in films.
